Undoing your last action
Undo your last action: CTRL + Z
Camera Movement
Use the arrow keys, or:
Scroll Forward: W
Scroll Left: A
Scroll Backward: S
Scroll Right: D
Camera Rotation
Use CTRL + Mouse, or
Rotate camera view clockwise: CTRL + Right Arrow key
Rotate camera view counter-clockwise: CTRL + Left Arrow key
Camera Zoom
Zoom In: + (plus key)
Zoom Out: - (minus key)
Switching between game views
Switch between overhead view & Zoo Guest mode: G
Switch between Zoo Guest mode & Photo Safari view: C
Toggle overview map on/off: TAB
Main game panels
Open/close Construction panel: CTRL + C
Open/close Animal panel: CTRL + M
Open/close Landscaping panel: CTRL + T
Open/close Staff panel: CTRL + H
Open the Photo Album: CTRL + P
Open Scenario Goals dialog box: CTRL + G
Display Zoo Finances: CTRL + F
Save/Load
Save Game: F5
Load Game: F6
Zoopedia
Show/Hide Zoopedia: F1
Rotating objects
>: Rotate current object clockwise
<: Rotate current object counter-clockwise
Painting under fences with biome brush
When using the mouse to change terrain or paint water or biome elements onto your zoo landscape, you can press and hold the SHIFT key to also make the changes to the areas underneath fences and barriers.
Recycling objects
Depending on what you select first when using the bulldozer to recycle objects you've placed, you can delete all of a certain type of object with a single sweep of the mouse.
For example, if you click the Recycle button and then select a tree you want to remove, you can remove all of the trees in your landscape at once by sweeping the mouse over the terrain.
The same holds true when you are recycling buildings, paths, fences, etc. To recycle all objects, regardless of their type, from the terrain, click on an area that is free of objects, and then sweep your mouse over the terrain.

Use this button to play the game in challenge mode, with few rules.
In challenge games, you begin with a very limited budget and an equally limited set of available animals, foliage, structures, and path types.
As you increase your Zoo Fame score, more choices will become available. New choices also become available as you fund research on specific objects.
When you complete a challenge, you may unlock reward-themed objects you can use to beautify your zoo.

Use this button to play the game in freeform mode, with no rules.
When you play a freeform game in Zoo Tycoon 2, all the animals and objects in the game are unlocked and available, and you have an unlimited budget.
A freeform game is like a giant sandbox, where you can experiment with building amazing exhibits without having to worry about running out of money.

Use this button to play the game in campaign mode.
The campaign games featured in Zoo Tycoon 2 are designed to let you explore many different aspects of being a zookeeper, starting with the basics of zoo creation and then moving on to more robust challenges.
When you select a campaign game, you will be challenged to complete a series of scenarios that are related to the campaign's central theme.
The first two campaign games, "Zoo Tycoon 2 Tutorial" and "Zookeeper-in-Training," include scenarios that introduce you to many game basics: moving around and camera controls, construction tools, and ways to find information and get feedback on how you're doing.
In the "Troubled Zoos" campaign game, your scenario tasks include rebuilding a dilapidated zoo, improving living conditions for animals, and rehabilitating and healing a zoo full of sick animals.
Some campaigns are locked when you first start the game. You must successfully complete all of the scenarios in the previous campaign in order to unlock the next one.

Click this button to open the Game Options screen, where you can:
-Customize your performance settings to make the game run faster.
-Adjust the volume levels of both music and ambient sound effects.
-Specify your sound card provider.
-Turn the "Message of the Day" feature on or off.
-Turn the "Enable Mouse Look" feature on or off.
Message of the Day
When you select the "Enable Message of the Day" option, the game automatically connects to the Internet to download and display messages whenever you start the game.
The messages consist of interesting facts or tidbits relating to Zoo Tycoon 2, or animals and zoos in general. The messages are displayed along the bottom of the main Zoo Tycoon 2 menu each time you start the game.
Enable Mouse Look
When you select the "Enable Mouse Look" option, you can use your mouse and the mouse wheel to look around while in Zoo Guest mode.

Click this button to open the Downloads screen, where you can review a list of official downloadable content from Microsoft that is currently available to add to your game. The detailed list includes information on the content of the download, the size of download, and the number of files included.
When you choose to download content, the game automatically connects to the Internet to complete the downloading process.
Since new downloads become available all the time, it's a good idea to check the Downloads screen often to find new and updated content. You never know what you may find!
Use this button to load a previously-saved game.
Use this button to exit Zoo Tycoon 2.

Photo Safari mode is a shutterbug's dream: it's where you can take photos of anything you can see in your zoo, from pooping pandas to goggle-eyed guests.
Click the camera icon in the lower left corner of the main game window to switch to Photo Safari mode, and then follow the on-screen instructions.
The roll of film in your camera has a 24-photo capacity. Once you've taken 24 shots, you will need to move some of the photos from your roll into photo albums before you can take any more shots.
Click the Photo Album button on the main game panel to open Photo Album view, where you can organize your photos into as many albums as you like. You can also share your photo albums with others by exporting them in this view. The photos are exported in jpg format.
In Photo Album view, you can also enlarge your photos, and delete the ones you don't like.

Welcome to Zoo Tycoon 2, the action-packed sequel to the award-winning Zoo Tycoon.
In Zoo Tycoon 2, you'll find both fun and financial success when you focus on the following:
Building great exhibits
Making animals and guests happy
Encouraging reproduction among your animals
Managing your zoo funds effectively
Hiring hardworking staff members (or completing zookeeper tasks yourself)
Making your zoo beautiful
To learn about the basics (and beyond) of building and maintaining the perfect zoo, it's a good idea to complete the tutorial campaigns featured in Campaign game mode. These tutorials cover everything from changing views to digging ditches to adopting animals, and they serve as the perfect introduction to Zoo Tycoon 2.

There are four different ways to view all of the action in your zoo. You can switch between views by clicking on the view buttons that appear in the lower left corner of the game window.
Overview map view
The overview map is most useful when you want to locate and go to a specific object in your zoo. For example, you may need to locate a specific brown bear in the zoo that needs your attention. In overview map view, all you have to do is click the brown bear icon on the map, and the view will jump to that animal.
The overview map includes icons that represent all of the paths, buildings, and animals currently placed in your zoo. You can click on an object's icon on the map to move directly to that object's current location.
Overhead view
Overhead view is the default view in Zoo Tycoon 2, the view you see when you first start the game.
Overhead view is most useful when you are working on your zoo layout, placing paths and fences, building exhibits, and placing buildings.
You can use the arrow controls on the main game panel to rotate your view in a clockwise or counter-clockwise direction, and you can use the plus and minus buttons to zoom your view in and out.
Zoo Guest mode
Zoo Guest mode is the first-person view in Zoo Tycoon 2 that lets you get up close and personal with both your animal inhabitants and with your zoo guests.
In Zoo Guest mode, you can view your zoo through the eyes of the guests who flock through your entrance gates, but you also have the option of taking it one step further.
In Zoo Guest mode, you can take on all the tasks that are usually assigned to a zookeeper, from feeding and watering animals to grooming and healing them, even cleaning up piles of their poop.
To complete a zookeeper task on your own in Zoo Guest mode, all you have to do is approach an animal and then follow the on-screen instructions.
It's important to remember that you can save yourself the cost of hiring a zookeeper if you take on zookeeper duties yourself in Zoo Guest mode.
Photo Safari view
In Photo Safari view, you can take photographs of all the animals and objects in your zoo and share them with your friends.

In Zoo Guest mode, you can view your zoo through the eyes of the guests who flock through your entrance gates, but you also have the option of taking it one step further.
In Zoo Guest mode, you can take on all the tasks that are usually assigned to a zookeeper, from feeding and watering animals to grooming and healing them, even cleaning up piles of their poop.
To complete a zookeeper task on your own in Zoo Guest mode, all you have to do is approach an animal and then follow the on-screen instructions.
It's important to remember that you can save yourself the cost of hiring a zookeeper if you take on zookeeper duties yourself in Zoo Guest mode.

So, you want to be a zoo tycoon. Check out the tips below to help get started.
The best zoo layouts are usually the result of advanced planning. The smartest thing you can do when starting out is plan for the future growth and expansion of your zoo.
By taking a moment to stop and strategize before throwing cash, fencing, and path tiles willy-nilly, you can save money in the short term while also creating a more hospitable environment for both your resident animals and their guests.
Top 10 zoo layout tips
1. Wide open spaces are a good thing. Spread things out to leave room for future expansion, and don't bunch your zoo's biggest attractions all in one place.
2. A standard grid layout, with paths around large exhibits or groups of smaller exhibits, can be a solid way to start. Just make sure that the animals have enough room in any smaller exhibits.
3. A fork layout, in which your zoo's main paths are divided by a space 2–5 tiles wide, is another good option for zoos designed to accommodate large numbers of guests. Populate the open spaces with guest amenities and scenery objects, or create additional paths to ease traffic flow.
4. In general, bigger is better when it comes to building exhibits. The more animals an exhibit contains, the more attractive the exhibit and the more money people will put into your donation boxes. Zoo guests also receive more educational value from exhibits with multiple animals.
5. Place gift shops and ATMs near the entrance to your zoo to encourage guests to make purchases before they exit.
6. To encourage traffic flow, place the exhibits for the most popular animals in the farthest reaches of your zoo. This will encourage your guests to dine, shop, stroll, and spend more time in your zoo.
7. Build observation areas between a path and an exhibit. Simply lay down a short stretch of pathway alongside the exhibit. This gives guests a place to view the exhibit without clogging the pathways.
8. Whenever possible, include the zoo perimeter wall as part of an exhibit's fencing. This saves money on fences, and also encourages building exhibits on the outer edges of your zoo.
9. Your zoo's visual aesthetics make a big impact on the happiness levels of your guests. Don't be afraid to invest in flowerbeds, fountains, and other scenery objects with visual (even if not practical) appeal. Guests enjoy looking at neat objects like themed trash cans and food stands.
10. Place staff gates to keep guests out of areas you don't want them to visit. Only staff members may pass through staff gates.

With the biome brush and habitat editor tools in Zoo Tycoon 2, you can forget about blisters, backaches, and even botany when building great exhibits.
The biome brush
You can take the guesswork out of the plant selection process and unlock the mysteries of exhibit foliage placement when you use the biome brush tool to quickly create lushly landscaped environments. A sweep of the biome brush fills your exhibit with terrain and vegetation appropriate to the biome type you've selected.
Whether you're creating an exhibit based on an African savannah, Arctic tundra, a tropical rain forest, wetlands, or a desert biome, the biome brush offers a shortcut to finding and placing the best types of plants, trees, shrubs, grasses, rocks, and water types for that specific environment, all at a reasonable cost.
With the biome brush, you can choose from a range of different terrain and deep and shallow water tools that are associated with each biome type.
Habitat editor tools
You can wield the power of backhoes, bulldozers, and other earth-moving equipment to quickly create mountains, valleys, and more as you build the ultimate animal exhibits using the habitat editor tools.
With these tools, you can manipulate terrain to create waterfalls, elevated walkways, and natural boundaries for the zoo of your dreams.
More advice on building exhibits
When calculating exhibit size, build exhibits large enough to accommodate a family (or variety) of animals, even if you're only starting out with one.
Although zoo guests like to see the animals up close, respect your animals' need for privacy. Building exhibits with a combination of solid and clear walls is a good way to take care of both your animals' and your zoo guests' needs.
Click the Zookeeper Recommendations button on the Animal Information panel to view the recommended food, toys, shelter, fences, rocks, and plants for a specific animal.
Jump into Zoo Guest mode while laying down paths and exhibit areas to see what it's like as a guest walking through your zoo.
Experiment with creating large multi-species exhibits that house more than one kind of animal. For example, a mixed-use savannah exhibit can potentially accommodate black rhinos, common zebras, reticulated giraffes, elephants, Thomson's gazelles and, the "King of Beasts," the lion. Guests love to see multiple kinds of animals co-existing in an exhibit and, as a result, will put more money in your donation boxes.

Fences have many uses in the Zoo Tycoon 2 world, from forming sturdy yet see-through barriers between guest and beast to prettying up public areas and directing the flow of traffic.
Choosing the right type of fencing for your specific needs is crucial to the success of your zoo. You need to find the right balance between protecting your guests and giving them unbridled visual access to your animal inhabitants.
Zoo Tycoon 2 offers three different methods for placing fences:
Rubber-band fence placement
Rubber-band placement mode is most useful when you want to build a custom-shaped fence. Click to start placing the fence, and then move the mouse to place additional fence sections in any shape you like.
You can also stretch the fence like a rubber band (thus, the name). When you're finished, click the mouse button to release the fence from the cursor.
Rectangular fence placement
Rectangular fence placement mode works best when you want to create a square- or rectangular-shaped fenced area automatically. Click to start placing the fence, and then move the mouse to adjust the size of the fenced area. Click again to place the enclosure.
After you create the fenced enclosure, you will be prompted to place a staff gate (this gives your zookeepers direct access to the animals within the enclosure) and a donation box (at least one should be placed near each exhibit to encourage donation from guests).
Octagonal fence placement
Octagonal fence placement mode is perfect for creating more rounded fence enclosures. It works the same way as rectangular fence placement mode. Click to start placing your fence, and then move the mouse to adjust the size of the fenced area. Click again to place the enclosure.

When placing paths, it's a good idea to focus on ensuring the smooth flow of guest traffic through your zoo by placing paths that are wide enough (three tiles wide, for example) to accommodate large numbers of guests. You want to avoid bottlenecks in food service areas and also make sure your guests are encouraged to explore every nook and cranny of the amazing zoo environment you've created.
Paths that are too steep for guests to climb are highlighted in yellow. When this happens, it's a good idea to either re-route the path or smooth the terrain to reduce the severity of the incline.

The wide range of buildings and other structures available in Zoo Tycoon 2 runs the gamut from restrooms and snack carts to fountains, playground equipment, compost buildings, and more.
Most buildings are designed to generate income by meeting the needs of your human guests, who are usually focused on food and drink, a clean bathroom, and a place to rest, along with souvenir shopping and educational opportunities.
Whenever you are placing a building or scenery object, a green arrow is displayed that shows where the "front" of the building or object is located.
It's important to place the front of buildings in locations where guests can easily enter and exit. If you position the front of a building or object in a location where guests can't access it, your chances for high sales volume are slim.
The key to success when placing buildings and scenery objects is to rotate the building or object before you place it. See below for details.
Rotating buildings or objects
To rotate the position of a building or other object before you place it in your zoo (once it's placed, you won't be able to rotate it), you have three options:
Use the < and > keys to rotate the object in either direction immediately before you place it.
Use the arrows in the Object Information panel to rotate the position of the selected object before placing it onto your zoo grid.
Rotate an object in place immediately before placing it by pressing and holding the left mouse button and moving the mouse. Release the left mouse button to place it.

Every zoo you create in Zoo Tycoon 2 is assigned a zoo fame score on a scale of between 1 and 5 stars. Your zoo fame score is always displayed in the upper-left corner of the main game window.
Your zoo fame score is determined by a combination of factors:
Number of Animals
The more animals you have in your zoo, the more famous it becomes. Add animals to your zoo to increase your fame.
Number of Species
Having multiple species in your zoo makes it more famous. Try adopting animals from many different species in order to become as famous as possible!
Animal Happiness
Even if you have lots of animals from many different kinds of species, if they aren’t happy then your zoo won’t be famous. Keep your animals happy by meeting their needs.
Educational Habitats
Guests are educated by seeing animals in their native habitats. If you make sure each animal in your zoo is in an appropriate habitat then your zoo is more educational. Educational zoos are more famous.
Entertaining Animals
Guests like having a good view of healthy, happy, and active animals. They also like rare and exotic animals. To ensure guests are enjoying your animals make sure the animals are happy, they have lots of things to do, and that guests can view them from close-up.
Guest Happiness
Even if your zoo is educational and your animals are very entertaining, if your guests aren’t happy, then your zoo won’t be famous. Keep your guests happy by meeting their needs.
Goals
Your zoo can become more famous by meeting challenges and earning awards. You won’t lose this fame. This is not counted in scenario games.
Release to Wild
Releasing animals into the wild increases the fame for your zoo. You won’t lose this fame.

Zoo Tycoon 2 offers a wide variety of animals to adopt, including rare, expensive animals that have the potential to make or break your zoo’s fame rating.
When you play a freeform game, all the animals are available from the start. In challenge games, you start out with four available animals, and additional animal slots are unlocked as you increase your zoo fame score.
Basic and advanced needs
Once you’ve adopted an animal and placed it in your zoo, it’s time to focus on meeting its basic and advanced needs.
The Animal Information panel, which you can view by clicking on any animal in your zoo, provides a summary of each individual animal’s current basic and advanced needs status, as well as information about its preferred environments.
Stimulating animals in captivity
There are three primary ways to stimulate your animal inhabitants and fulfill their basic and advanced needs.
Visits from the zookeeper -- Animals will always respond positively to individual attention from a zookeeper. In Zoo Guest mode, you can take on all of a zookeeper’s tasks yourself, from feeding and watering to grooming and healing sick animals.
The companionship of other animals -- Even the most solitary of animals in your zoo would probably be happier sharing their exhibit with a potential mate.
Animal enrichment objects (toys) -- Toys encourage animals to use their natural skills and behaviors. Zoo guests love to see animals playing with toys.
Encouraging reproduction
Animals reproducing in your zoo is one of your ultimate signs of success—it means you have satisfied the basic and advanced needs of the fledgling’s parents, making them so happy and comfortable that they’ve had time to turn their attention to each other.
You also get economic benefits from the birth of an animal. Zoo guests find baby animals more interesting than adult animals—this means they spend more time watching them and may even be inspired to donate more money to your zoo.
Releasing animals into the wild
Releasing animals into the wild is another ultimate sign of success in Zoo Tycoon 2. It increases your zoo fame score, and you can also expect an award.
You can also put animals up for adoption, which makes them available to other zoos.
In order to be eligible to release an animal into the wild, you must first satisfy all of its basic and advanced needs.

All of the guests who show up at your entrance gates arrive with favorite animals, foods, and attractions, not to mention different levels of thirst, hunger, and fatigue.
There are two easy ways to quickly check in on your zoo guests to see how they're doing:
First, you can click on any individual guest in your zoo to display the Guest Information panel in the lower right corner of the main game window. The Guest Information panel includes lots of detailed information about what that specific guest is thinking and feeling.
Second, you can click the View Quick Stats button on the main game panel to display the complete list of guests currently visiting your zoo. On the View Quick Stats screen, you can sort your guest list based on favorite animals, happiness levels, bathroom need, and more.
Check out the tips below for more advice on how to keep your zoo guests happy and satisfied.
Top 10 tips for attracting guests to your zoo
1. Give 'em room. Build paths that leave plenty of elbow room for the crowds. Large viewing areas near popular exhibits also keep crowds happy.
2. Keep it clean. Placing recycling bins and trash cans around your zoo can help keep things spotless.
3. Showcase popular animals, and include as many different species as possible (this will have a huge effect on your zoo fame score!).
4. Provide facilities where guests can be fed, watered, and rested, and they'll be happy. They're not so different from your animal inhabitants, in fact.
5. Encourage reproduction among your animals. Zoo guests love baby animals.
6. Experiment with changing the price of zoo admission and zoo concessions until you find the perfect balance between keeping guests happy (and spending!) and maximizing your profit potential.
7. Guests like to be amused while in the zoo. In addition to viewing animals, they like to admire interesting statues, fountains, and themed areas. Kids love to play on playground equipment.
8. Pay attention to your zoo's aesthetics. Flowers and fountains can make a real difference in your guests' happiness levels.
9. Guests are happiest when viewing happy, healthy animals in well-designed exhibits.
10. Guests also want to be educated. Seeing animals in exhibits that represent their natural biomes may prompt guests to donate more money to your zoo.

Income from donations
Donations are your primary source of income when you're running a zoo. Zoo guests who enjoyed their visit to your zoo have the potential to make donations.
Guests who have seen interesting animals do interesting things may place money in the zoo donation boxes you place outside of your zoo exhibits.
Guests are also often inspired to make education donations when they see animals in exhibits that represent their natural biomes.
Admission income
You can change the admission price for your zoo at any time by clicking on the Zoo Status button on the main game panel.
When you lower your admission fees, your guests may have more spending money to purchase food, drinks, and souvenirs while visiting your zoo.
Income from food and drink concessions
Every food and drink concession, from the lowliest dessert cart to the fanciest restaurant, has upkeep costs associated with it. The key to your success will be to find concessions that turn a profit after the upkeep costs have been paid.
Although restaurants are expensive to build and maintain, they can also be huge moneymakers. Since they offer seating areas, wait staff, and trash disposal, they are enormously attractive to guests of all ages.
Income from gift carts and gift shops
Few things in life make guests happier than purchasing a souvenir of their visit.
Both the gift carts and the gift shops in Zoo Tycoon 2 sell gifts associated with specific animals. When guests enjoy looking at a certain animal in your zoo, they're usually thrilled to buy a gift that represents that animal.
Gift carts have a low upkeep cost, but they also stock low-priced gifts that represent the basic animals in your zoo.
With a larger inventory of souvenirs, the gift shop has the potential to be a big moneymaker. Gift shops have higher upkeep costs, but they also stock higher-priced gifts.
A gift shop's location in your zoo will have a major impact on its revenues. Be sure to place gift shops in high-traffic areas and close to your entrance gates.
Income from recycling
When you remove a building or scenery object, you receive a recycling fee that helps recoup the object's original cost.
You can also turn poop into profits by building a compost building in a discreet location away from food service areas and your zoo guests.
Guests will throw the trash from the coffee and sparkling water stands in recyling bins. When these bins are emptied you will generate some profit.
